addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable the Lordes and others of her Ma
ties
most honorable privy Councell.

26th Decemb
r
1589
From M
r
Bodleighe.

page.lettertext:
fol.219r
Belgia 1589 De
c
26.
It may please yo
r
LL. to be advertised,
at
according to
e teno
r
of yo
r
letters of
e 12
of No
v
whiche came to my handes the 13 of this
moneth, at
e next Assemblie of
e
Generall states
I proposed unto them, what course her Ma
tie
had
taken, to repare
e sea breaches, and ruines at
Ostend
: wherof I required their publicke Act of
approbation, according to yo
r
LL. direction.
Howbeit
e copie
it self of
e order, wherof yo
r
LL. make mention, I have not receaved.
That they have not satisfied her Ma
tie
w
t
some answear
to
e last proposition, whiche I made unto them, by
yo
r
commaundem
t
, they doe alleage for excuse,
at
they delivered their advise to
e
Councell of State
,
about
e same time, and in
e same mater, wherof
they say they were persuaded, that I being a member
of
e Councell, would have certified her Ma
tie
. And
concerning the present order, whiche is taken by her
Hig
nes
they will intimat nothing of their liking or
disliking of it: but have only declared
at they will
acquaint their Principals w
t
it: finding that of them
selves they are not sufficiently autorised, to varie
in any thing from their Contract w
t
her Ma
tie
.
This is the effect of that Answear whiche they retur-
ned unto me: wherunto I thought it my duty to
replie againe, for
at I see they have framed their
Answear but for forme, w
t
out any taken of care
to yelde her Ma
tie
satisfaction. For I did my
last message unto them
e 10 of Sep
t
and after
for
e space of a moneth was a continuall solicito
r
unto them for some resoluc
o
n, and could not obtene
it. Only
e 8 of Oc
t
uppon
e instance of a letter
sent from Ostend to
e Councell of state, whiche
ei
sent to
e Generall states, they returned a short
fol.219v
schedule, contening their opinion to e said letter, w
t
out
any signification of it unto me, or ins
[inua]
tion of
any answear
at I should make uppon it to her Ma
tie
.
The effect of their opinion was, that
e Councell of state
should endevo
r
by
their letters to persuade the
states
of Zeland
, to defray
e charges of
e Fortifications
of Ostend. Whiche was no advise to be certified,
for that they knewe well enough, and they were told
it also by
e Deputies of Zeland, whiche were heere
at that time, that it was in vaine for
e Councell to
make any suche motion, for that
e states of Ze-
land were
fully then resolved, to beare but their
owne portion w
t
e rest of
e Provinces.
Likewise for
e second point of their Answear, wheras
they collo
r
their refusall of ratifieng
, by their
publike Act, the
order whiche is nowe taken by
her Ma
tie
for want of sufficient autoritie from
their
Principals, it is
e same dilatorie Answear w
ch
they made unto me the 6 of Au
g
last, uppon
that I proposed unto them, about accepting the
1200 foote for 600 horse: and likewise the same
moneth,
e 14 day, uppon
e motion w
ch
I made,
concerning
e inlarging of their Deputies commissi-
on then in
England
, wherein there was never
any thing yet effectually perfourmed on their
part, nor their Principals intention notified to
her Ma
tie
. This I have signified somwhat large
ly
unto them, and declared w
t
all, that forasmuch
as they doe often pretend the want of sufficient
Commission, it would be very requisit that her
Hig
nes
should be made acquainted w
t
that Commission
which they have at this present from their Princi-
palls, whereby it may appeare directly and distinctly
unto her, as also to her servants
at are imploied in
fol.220r
these Contreis, howe farre it doth extend, and to whome
they may addresse themselves, according to
e nature
of every occurrence: wheras otherwise, thinges conti-
nuing in suche termes, as they doe at this present,
there is a great deale of time spent in proceeding
impertinently, and theruppon muche occasion of dis-
contentment ministred, to
e speciall prejudice as-
well of her Ma
tie
as of themselves and their supe-
rio
rs
. The copies of my Replie to this their Ans-
wear, together w
t
their Answear, and my Proposition,
and also a transcript of
e forsaid schedule sent
to
e Councell of state, M
r
Secretary will vouchesafe
to shewe unto yo
r
LL. Moreover,
t[.]t
it may
please yo
r
LL. to understand, that after I had
dealt in this cause of Ostend w
t
e Generall States,
I imparted
e whole to
e Councell of state, who
seemed not to dislike of her Ma
ties
order, conditio-
nally that some of their owne Officers might be
jointly autorised w
t
her Ma
ties
in
for
over
seeing the
woorkes, and disboursing
e mony. And so I finde
that in most thinges the Councell of state is inclined
to proceede w
t
good correspondence and satisfaction
of her Ma
tie
whiche notw
t
standing is commonly im-
peached by some among
e Generall states, who
are ever backwardly affected so that her Ma
tie
would
sette forward.
And thus I take my humble
leave. From
e Hage. 26 De
c
89.
Yo
r
LL. most humble
at commaundem
t
Tho. Bodley
